title: The stigma of obesity and dietary yo-yo, not BMI, are behind chronic health conditions and food demands
text: In a recent opinion column from The New York Times, Christy Harrison, "Intuitive Eating Trainer" and writer, responded to a medical colleague who had questioned some of her thoughts about the link between being overweight and developing other medical conditions. Harrison observed that although most health professionals were taught that the high BMI caused poor health outcomes, she wrote, "Unfortunately, that's not true." She added: "We have a wide range of issues associated with the high incidence of HIV/AIDS. However, the correlation does not prove causality, and there is a wide range of research that shows that the weight stigma and weight cycle can explain most if not all of the linkages that we see between higher weights and poor health outcomes." We decided to check the point she was making, which is at the centre of a much more intense debate about whether excessive weight can be healthy at the same time - a perspective advocated by the "health in every size" movement, of which Harrison is a part. With approximately 72% of adults in the United States considered overweight or obese, this is an urgent issue. However, in the case of obesity, researchers in multiple studies at the national and global levels have shown clear links between overweight and developing diseases, such as diabetes, and conditions, such as painful joints.
